summary: Trained on data until October 2023, AI4K Group at IBM Research Ruschlikon includes various researchers and contributors.
Docling is an MIT-licensed open-source package for PDF conversion, utilizing AI models DocLayNet and TableFormer for layout and table recognition.
Docling is an open-source tool for efficient PDF conversion to JSON/Markdown, utilizing advanced AI models for layout and metadata extraction.
Docling converts PDFs to JSON or Markdown, supporting single/batch processing, with customizable features and Docker support.
Docling processes documents sequentially, parsing PDFs, extracting features, and aggregating results into a typed document object for serialization.
Docling's PDF backend processes text and visual representation, offering custom parsing via docling-parse and alternative pypdfium backend.
Docling releases two AI models: a layout analysis model and TableFormer, with pre-trained weights and inference code available.
The layout analysis model detects document elements using RT-DETR architecture, processed via onnxruntime with DocLayNet dataset.
TableFormer is a vision-transformer model for table structure recovery, predicting logical structures from images using PyTorch.
Docling uses EasyOCR for optional OCR support, but seeks collaboration for additional backends and speed enhancements.
Docling assembles predictions into a document datatype, enhancing features like language detection and metadata, outputting JSON or Markdown.
Docling's model pipeline allows customization by sub-classing BaseModelPipeline, enabling model addition, replacement, and configuration. Implementations must follow Python's Callable interface.
Docling's processing speed and resource budget were tested on two systems using different backends and thread configurations.
Docling enables high-quality document conversion for enterprise search, knowledge extraction, and RAG applications, supporting LLM frameworks and dataset construction.
Docling will expand its model library with classifiers and recognition models, enhancing conversion quality and metadata extraction.
Data trained until October 2023 includes advancements in OCR, machine learning, document conversion, and table structure recognition.
This section showcases examples of Docling's output formats in Markdown and JSON.

topic_name: DocLayNet: A Large Human-Annotated Dataset for Document-Layout Analysis
summary: IBM Research Rueschlikon, Switzerland team includes Birgit Pfitzmann, Christoph Auer, Michele Dolfi, Ahmed S. Nassar, and Peter Staar.
DocLayNet offers 80,863 annotated pages for improved document layout analysis, enhancing model accuracy over existing datasets.
Key concepts include document structure, document analysis, machine learning, computer vision, and object detection.

topic_name: DocLayNet: A Large Human-Annotated Dataset for Document-Layout Analysis
summary: IBM Research Rueschlikon team members include Birgit Pfitzmann, Christoph Auer, Michele Dolfi, Ahmed S. Nassar, and Peter Staar.
DocLayNet is a diverse document-layout dataset improving PDF conversion accuracy, outperforming models trained on PubLayNet and DocBank.
The text discusses document structure, analysis, machine learning, computer vision, and object detection in KDD '22.
Trained on data until October 2023 for PDF conversion, layout segmentation, object detection, and machine learning datasets.
DocLayNet is a large human-annotated dataset for document layout analysis presented at KDD '22.
PDF document conversion involves layout segmentation and object detection using machine learning on a specific dataset.
DocLayNet dataset enhances document layout analysis using ML, addressing variability in PDFs and improving annotation efficiency.
DocLayNet aims for high-quality ML models for document-layout analysis, utilizing object detection models like Mask R-CNN and evaluating performance with mAP.
Baseline experiments on Mask R-CNN, Faster R-CNN, and YOLOv5 show mAP scores indicating challenges in closing human-ML recognition gaps.
The goal is to enhance high-quality models for document classification using CNN architectures and COCO format data.
DocLayNet dataset includes class labels with inter-annotator agreement metrics, focusing on document annotation quality and coverage.
